title: The science that shows it's hard to beat the market
text:
He explains that although academia has closely studied lots of different types of risk and uncertainty, an unexplored frontier is uncertainty stemming from complexity.

There are lots of things in life that are very complex, and yet humans manage to do a pretty good job of dealing with that complexity. Trading oil might be one example, but so is deciding what order to do things in the morning, given the endless possibilities.

Perfect foresight

He’s interested in how humans cope with this complexity, whether we can get better at managing it, and how markets might provide some help.

Which brings us to his paper.

The idea that prices are always right relies on the concept of perfect foresight – that is, those in the market are somehow super-human and can know prices in all contingencies.

Clearly, markets are far too complex even to try to do that. And we know from behavioural scientists including Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky (the psychologists who starred in Michael Lewis’s terrific book, The Undoing Project) that people aren’t like that.

They tend to be pretty myopic and use what Kahneman and Tversky call “narrow framing” to make decisions based on what they know about their own circumstances.

Advertisement

So if humans are so flawed, how can prices magically be right?

To find out, Bossaerts ran a series of experiments where he had groups of people trade commodities for a period. What he found, essentially, was that people do throw their hands up at the complexity in markets and use narrow framing to make their decisions.

Essentially, they ignore that they might have the ability to retrade that commodity in the future, and make their decisions based on their own supply and demand needs.

The majority of people act in the same way, creating a sort of collective rationality

The “magic” comes from the fact that the majority of people act in the same way, creating a sort of collective rationality.

“Because personal supplies add up to the total supply, it’s as if we’re actually trading the whole market,” Bossaerts says.

He says this helps explains why index investing can be the best way to play public markets.

But that doesn’t mean mispricing opportunities don’t exist, and the more speculation there is in a market – that is, the less people use narrow framing and start trying to second guess future contingencies in a market – the bigger the opportunity to find that mispricing.

This is the great hope for asset managers, and helps explain why many are turning to alternative investments – private equity and other forms of private capital – to find returns.

“There are plenty of markets where if you see speculation, you just go for it and try and figure out what’s wrong,” Bossaerts says.
description: As the hunt for yield gets harder, new work from Melbourne-based Professor Peter Bossaerts shows why index investing is a good bet.
